'''11''' (''[[2008â2009 figure skating season|2008â2009]]'') |combined total= 233.04 |combined date= [[2010 Skate Canada International|2010 Skate Canada]] |SP score= 80.11 |SP date= [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 Worlds]] |FS score= 156.22 |FS date= [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2010 Four Continents]] |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry| [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure Skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Four Continents Championships]]}} {{MedalGold| [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2010 Jeonju]] | [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Men's Singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2009 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2009 Sofia]]|[[2009 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2008 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2008 Sofia]]|[[2008 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix Final]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2007â2008 Junior Grand Prix|2007â2008 GdaÅsk]]|[[2007â2008 Junior Grand Prix|Men's singles]]}} }} '''Adam Rippon''' (born November 11, 1989) is an American [[figure skater]]. He is the 2010 [[Four Continents Championships|Four Continents champion]], the 2008 and 2009 [[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior champion]], the 2008 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships|U.S. junior national champion]], and the 2007â2008 [[2007â2008 Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix Final champion]]. == Personal life == Adam Rippon was born in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]]. He is the oldest of six children. Rippon was born deaf but underwent surgery at Yale University when he was young which allows him to hear almost perfectly. He started to skate at age ten because his mother skated and brought him along to the rink. == Career == === Early career === Rippon started to skate at age 10 because his mother skated and brought him along to the rink. In the 2004â2005 season, Adam Rippon won the silver medal on the novice level at the [[2005 United States Figure Skating Championships|2005 U.S. Championships]]. In the 2005â2006 season, Rippon debuted on the [[ISU Junior Grand Prix]] circuit. He competed at the [[2005-2006 ISU Junior Grand Prix]] event in Croatia and placed 6th. He was not assigned to a second Junior Grand Prix event. At the [[2006 United States Figure Skating Championships|2006 U.S. Championships]], he finished 11th at the junior level. In the 2006â2007 season, Rippon did not compete on the Junior Grand Prix circuit. He placed 6th on the junior level at the [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|2007 U.S. Championships]]. === 2007â2008 season === In the 2007â2008 season, Rippon competed on the [[2007-2008 Junior Grand Prix]] circuit. At his first event, the Harghita Cup in Miercurea Ciuc, Romania, he won the gold medal. He then won the silver medal at the Sofia Cup in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]]. These two medals qualified him for the [[2007-2008 Junior Grand Prix|2007â2008 Junior Grand Prix Final]]. At that event, Rippon won the gold medal, and became the first man to break 200 points at a Junior level competition. He went on to the [[2008 United States Figure Skating Championships|2008 U.S. Championships]], where he won the Junior title. The Professional Skaters Association recognized Rippon as having the best men's free skate. He earned a trip to the [[2008 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2008 Junior Worlds]], where he won the gold medal. He was the second American man in a row to win the title, after [[Stephen Carriere]], and the first man in years to win that title without attempting a [[triple axel]] jump.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} === 2008â2009 Season === Rippon moved up to the senior level in the 2008â2009 season. In the [[2008â2009 ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating|Grand Prix season]] he was assigned to compete at the [[2008 Skate America]] where he placed eighth, and the [[2008 Cup of Russia]] where he placed third in the short program and fifth overall. At the [[2009 United States Figure Skating Championships|2009 U.S. Championships]], his senior level national debut, he placed seventh. He was named to the team for the [[2009 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2009 Junior World Championships]]. At Junior Worlds, in his two programs, he landed a total of three [[axel jump|triple axel]] jumps, one in combination with a [[toe loop jump|double toe loop]]. He won the competition overall, scoring 222.00 points, becoming the first single skater to win two World Junior titles. === 2009â2010 season === Rippon sprained his ankle during the summer and missed some training time. For the 2009â2010 season, Rippon was assigned to two [[2009-2010 ISU Grand Prix|Grand Prix]] events. At the [[2009 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]], he landed a [[flip jump|triple flip]]-[[toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|triple axel]] and a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]] in the short program and placed third in that segment of the competition.{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/results/gpfra09/gpfra09_Men_SP_Scores.pdf | title = ISU GP Trophee Eric Bompard MEN SHORT PROGRAM JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER | date = 16 October 2009 | accessdate = 8 February 2010 | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] | format = PDF}} In the free skate, he landed a [[flip jump|triple flip]]-[[toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|triple axel]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]] combination, a [[loop jump|triple loop]], a [[axel jump|triple axel]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]]-[[loop jump|double loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|double axel]] and a [[salchow jump|triple salchow]] to place third in that segment of the competition.{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/results/gpfra09/gpfra09_Men_FS_Scores.pdf | title = ISU GP Trophee Eric Bompard MEN FREE SKATING JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER | date = 17 October 2009 | accessdate = 8 February 2010 | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] | format = PDF}} Rippon won the bronze medal with a total score of 219.96 points. At the [[2009 NHK Trophy]], Rippon placed eighth in the short program with a score of 67.15, after falling on the [[axel jump|triple axel]]. He placed fifth in the free skate with a score of 130.46, completing seven triples including the [[axel jump|triple axel]] in combination.{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/results/gpjpn09/gpjpn09_Men_FS_Scores.pdf | title = ISU GP NHK Trophy 2009 MEN FREE SKATING JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER | date = 7 November 2009 | accessdate = 8 February 2010 | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] | format = PDF}} Rippon placed sixth overall with a total score of 197.61 points. At the [[2010 United States Figure Skating Championships|2010 U.S. Championships]], he placed fourth in the short program with a score of 72.91 points after doubling with his triple lutz and falling in his [[Step sequence|footwork sequence]]. In the free skate, he completed eight triples and placed fourth in that segment of the competition with a score of 152.16 points.{{cite web | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/2010/64740/SEGM004.html | title = 2010 US Figure Skating Championships Championship Men Free Skate Judges' Details | date =17 January 2010 | accessdate = 8 February 2010| publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]]}} He finished fifth overall earning 225.07 points. Rippon was assigned to the [[2010 Four Continents Championships]].{{cite news | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/Story.asp?id=44092&type=media | title = U.S. Figure Skating Announces Men Nominated to 2010 U.S. Olympic Figure Skating Team | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] | date = January 17, 2010 | accessdate = January 18, 2010 }} At the 2010 Four Continents Championships, he placed seventh in the short program with a score of 69.56 points. In the free skate, he completed a [[flip jump|triple flip]]-[[toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|triple axel]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]] combination, a [[loop jump|triple loop]], a [[axel jump|triple axel]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]]-[[loop jump|double loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|double axel]] and a downgraded [[salchow jump|triple salchow]] to place first in that segment of that competition.{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2010/fc10_Men_FS_Scores.pdf | title = ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships MEN FREE SKATING JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER | date = 30 January 2010 | accessdate = 8 February 2010 | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] | format = PDF}} He won the gold medal with a total score of 225.78 points. Rippon competed at the [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 World Championships]]. He placed seventh in the short program with 80.11 points after landing a [[flip jump|triple flip]]-[[toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|triple axel]] and a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]]. In the free skate he came in fifth place with 231.47 points after executing [[flip jump|triple flip]]-[[toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|triple axel]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]] combination, a [[loop jump|triple loop]], a [[axel jump|triple axel]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]], a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]]-[[toe loop jump|double toe loop]]-[[loop jump|double loop]] combination, a [[axel jump|double axel]] and a [[salchow jump|triple salchow]]. Overall he placed sixth with 231.47 points. === 2010â2011 season === Rippon began his season at the Japan Open, where he finished ahead of [[Daisuke Takahashi]] and [[Evgeni Plushenko]]. His assigned Grand Prix events for the [[2010â2011 Grand Prix of Figure Skating|2010â2011 ISU Grand Prix]] season were the [[2010 Skate Canada International]] and the [[2010 Skate America]]. At the [[2010 Skate Canada International]], Rippon had a collision with [[Patrick Chan]] during the morning practice before the short program but stated, "That was definitely the most exciting collision, maybe not the most dangerous." He placed third in the short program with 77.53 points after executing a [[Axel jump|triple axel]], a [[Flip jump|triple flip]]-[[Toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination and a [[Lutz jump|triple lutz]]. He placed second in the free skate earning 155.51 points nailing a [[Axel jump|triple axel]]-[[Toe loop jump|double toe loop]] combination, a [[Axel jump|double axel]], a [[Lutz jump|triple lutz]], a [[Flip jump|triple flip]]-[[Toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[Lutz jump|triple lutz]]-[[Toe loop jump|double toe loop]]-[[Loop jump|double loop]] combination, a [[Loop jump|triple loop]] and a [[Salchow jump|triple salchow]] but stepping out of his second [[Axel jump|triple axel]]. He won the bronze medal overall scoring 233.04 points, a new personal best. At the [[2010 Skate America]], Rippon placed third in the short program with 73.94 points. He stepped out of his [[Axel jump|triple axel]], but executed a [[Flip jump|triple flip]]-[[Toe loop jump|triple toe loop]] combination, a [[Lutz jump|triple lutz]] and all his spins were graded a level four. At the [[2011 United States Figure Skating Championships|2011 U.S. Championships]], Rippon finished 5th and was assigned to the [[2011 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2011 Four Continents]] but missed the [[2011 World Figure Skating Championships|World]] team. He was also 5th at Four Continents. During the off-season, he worked on a quad lutz. === 2011â2012 season === In the [[2011â2012 figure skating season|2011â2012 season]], Rippon is assigned to [[2011 Skate Canada]] and [[2011 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]] as his [[2011â12 ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating|Grand Prix]] events. ==Coaching changes== Rippon was coached by Yelena Sergeeva from 2000â2007. He changed coaches following the [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|2007 U.S. Championships]] and began working with [[Nikolai Morozov (figure skater)|Nikolai Morozov]] in February 2007 at the Ice House in [[Hackensack, New Jersey]]. In late November 2008, Rippon left Morozov. In December 2008, he moved to [[Toronto]], [[Canada]] to begin being training with [[Brian Orser]] at the [[Toronto Cricket, Skating & Curling Club]]. Rippon officially announced his coaching change on January 2, 2009. On April 1, 2011, Rippon announced he would no longer be coached by Orser but would remain at the same club coached by Ghislain Briand, with whom he had already worked for over two years. On June 16, 2011, Rippon announced he was leaving Toronto to train with [[Jason Dungjen]] at the Detroit Skating Club in [[Bloomfield Hills, Michigan]], having been impressed with the facilities while working with DCS-based choreographer [[Pasquale Camerlengo]]. ==Signature moves== Rippon's signature move is a [[lutz jump|triple lutz]] that he executes with both arms on his head, popularly called the "'''Rippon Lutz'''". He is capable of performing the [[lutz jump|triple lutz]]-[[Toe loop jump|double toe loop]]-[[Loop jump|double loop]] combination with one hand over his head in all three jumps (popularly called the "'Tano Lutz" after [[Brian Boitano]], who invented the move). He is also one of the few men able to do a [[camel spin|donut spin]]. ==Programs== [[Image:Adam Rippon at the 2010 World Championships (1).jpg|thumb|Rippon performs his short program to [[Jonathan Livingston Seagull (film)|Jonathan Livingston Seagull]] at the [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships]].]] {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !
